rows.title: What is Safeguarding?

title.eng: What is Safeguarding?

introduction.eng:
It is important to know the following guidelines for handling disclosures of abuse, neglect, and violence from participants:

1ï¸âƒ£ **Understand abuse, neglect and exploitation.**

â— **Abuse** refers to a deliberate act of maltreatment that can damage a boy or girlâ€™s security, wellbeing, dignity and development. Abuse includes all forms of physical, sexual, psychological and emotional maltreatment. (Save the Children definition)

â— **Violence** against girls and boys is defined as forms of physical or mental violence, damage and abuse, neglect or neglectful treatment or maltreatment or exploitation, including sexual abuse. (Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, 1990,
Article 19)

â— **Child exploitation** refers to using girls and boys for economic or sexual benefit, gratification or profit, often resulting in unjust, cruel and harmful treatment of the girl or boy. (Save the Children definition)

2ï¸âƒ£ **Know your organisationâ€™s child safeguarding policies and referral procedures.**

ğŸ“– All organisations should have or develop child rights safeguarding policies and referral procedures, including details on how to respond appropriately when a caregiver, other adults, girl or boy discloses abuse. 

ğŸ“ You should have accurate knowledge of all protocols and response plans. These will tell you what to do within your organisation if a caregiver or girl or boy reports abuse (e.g. who to report to, internal resources for supporting the girl or boy), as well as how to engage outside resources (e.g. local referral pathways, when to engage with authorities). 

ğŸ”‘ It is your responsibility to act regardless of whether you are responding to disclosures of past and/or present abuse. However, you are not responsible for resolving the situation on your own. It is important that you discuss the situation with your supervisor to agree on what steps to take next.

3ï¸âƒ£ **Ensure parents know that you are someone who can help.**

ğŸŒ·Parents participating in your sessions need to know that they can come to you for help, regardless of when the abuse occurred. 

ğŸ‘‚You should make sure that they know that they can trust you and that you will listen and support them without judgment or any further harm.

âŒ Avoid engaging with the alleged abuser â€“ that may make things worse and make next steps difficult. It could also jeopardise future legal proceedings.

rows.title: After Onboarding Session

title.eng: After Onboarding Session

introduction.eng: This chat session should happen on the same day or day after you complete the in-person onboarding session. As the first chat session, it offers a chance for parents to introduce themselves to the group.

section_title_1.eng: Add Ground Rules to the WhatsApp Group Description

section_text_1.eng:
Remember to add the ground rules to the WhatsApp Group Description. â€‹â€‹To add the ground rules to the Group Description, copy the following ground rules or use the ones agreed during the onboarding session: â€œTo make this a safe space for everyone, here are some ground rules:
 
âœ… What is said in the group stays in the group. You need to know that this group is private.
âœ… Accept each other. Everyone is different and has different experiences.
âœ… Share only what you feel comfortable sharing. Avoid topics unrelated to the content of the workshop, advertisements or sales. 
âœ… Feel free to ask questions! 
âœ… Respect privacy of personal pictures and videos that are sent to the chat group. 
âœ… I AM only here as an observer. I will not respond to questions about your parenting habits in this group or personally. However, if there is a message that will benefit the entire group, then I will share a general message here.â€

Open the WhatsApp group chat. Tap the group name. Tap the existing description, or tap Add Group Description. 
Paste the ground rules. Tap Save.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ˜ƒ Hi there! Welcome to our Crianza con Conciencia+ WhatsApp Group! 

Today, we are introducing ourselves and our goals for the programme! â­ 

My name is [INSERT NAME], and my goal is to learn more about how to help my girl go to bed by 8 every night.â°ğŸŒ™ 

Please share your name and your goal for Crianza con Conciencia+ using text or audio message.

message_guidance_1.eng:
Remember to fill in your name where it says [INSERT NAME] before sending your message. 

Allow some time for parents to share. Try to praise each response.

For example, you can say, â€œThanks for the response, [Insert Name]!â€ or â€œGreat goal, [Insert Name]â€! You can also use simple emojis like ğŸ‘or ğŸ™‚

message_text_2.eng:
This week, we will catch up at [INSERT TIME] on [INSERT DAY] to chat about our Crianza con Conciencia+ journey. 

ğŸ‘‹Please join to share how things are going. Every little step matters. Share what works when you practice, reflections about the topic, any challenges you experience, or just say hi! ğŸ˜Š

â°Does this time and day work for everyone?

message_guidance_2.eng: Add the time and day of the week before sending the message.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸ˜ƒThank you so much for being part of our WhatsApp chat group! 

As your home practice, try to spend at least 5 minutes of one-on-one time with your girl, boy or teen each day. 

We can share how it goes during our next chat session. 

ğŸ‘‹See you later.

rows.title: Day 3: Self-Talk

title.eng: Day 3: Self-Talk

introduction.eng:
**Before conducting the chat sessions, make sure you:** 

Create a WhatsApp Group during the onboarding session. 
Identify the ground rules for the WhatsApp Group

**Structure for the chat sessions**: 

Day  1 (immediately after the onboarding session): Welcome, introductions, and reminder of home practice. 

Day 3: Self-talk: WhatsApp Chat session on self-talk and stress

Day 5: Saying Goodbye

**When to send the messages** 

You and your group will decide a time to chat during the onboarding session. 

Each chat session has a reminder message (Message 1) that you should send a few hours before the chat session. 

Send the remaining messages during the scheduled chat time.

message_text_1.eng: ğŸ’šHello everyone! Our next chat session will be later today at [INSERT TIME]. Chat soon!

message_guidance_1.eng: Send this message in the morning on the day of the chat session. Insert the time for the chat before sending the message.

message_text_2.eng:
Hello, everyone! ğŸ˜ƒ
Welcome to our second chat session! Today, we are talking about feeling stressed. Feeling stressed is a normal part of being human, and parenting can add an extra layer of challenges. Itâ€™s important to manage our stress. Otherwise, it can build up and affect our health and relationships!How is everyoneâ€™s stress level today? Use a number from 1 to 10 to share your stress level:
1 - No Stress 
2 to 5 - Some Stress 
6 to 9 - Feeling Stressed 
10 - Extremely Stressed 

Feel free to share your number with the group. We're all in this together!

message_guidance_2.eng: Allow time for parents to share how they are feeling. You should also share how you are feeling. For example, â€œToday, I'm at a 5 stress level, my teen has been sick for a few days but happy to be part of the chat today.â€

message_text_3.eng:
Thank you all for sharing your honest responses! ğŸ‰
ğŸ’¡ Today, we're going to practise a skill to manage stress: self-talk.
ğŸ¤ Self-talk is the way we talk to ourselves in our head or out loud during stressful situations. Itâ€™s the things we say to ourselves out loud and the thoughts in our minds.
It's easy to be unkind to ourselves, especially when we're tired or upset.
Can anyone share a time when they said something negative to themselves?

message_guidance_3.eng: Allow parents to respond. You can reply to the parents with an emoji â­ or words of encouragement, like â€œThat is a good example! I am sure a lot of us have felt that wayâ€.

message_text_4.eng:
Thanks for sharing that example! 
Parenting can be challenging. But you can reduce your overall stress when you think about what youâ€™re doing well and speak kindly to yourself. 

1ï¸âƒ£ The first step for practising self-talk is to notice when a negative thought comes.
2ï¸âƒ£Then, ask yourself: How can I change this thought into something kind or caring? You can: 
ğŸ˜ƒ Look for small parenting accomplishments or efforts. 
âœ… Consider what youâ€™ve learned from the negative situation. 
ğŸ“Come up with a few ways to help you act differently next time. Remember, this is temporary, and you have the chance to be better in the future.

message_text_5.eng:
ğŸ“ Let's notice negative self-talk when it happens, and turn it around. For example, 
**Negative Self-Talk:** "I was a bad parent today. I yelled at my teen for an honest mistake."
**Positive Self-Talk:** "Today was tough because I've been overwhelmed. I yelled at my teen, knowing it was an honest mistake. Next time, I'll pause before responding, ensuring I'm calm and in control."
ğŸ’¡ See how the positive self-talk is more supportive? ğŸ  Now, your turn! Share a time you talked negatively to yourself, and letâ€™s find and turn it into positive self-talk. Try doing this three times by the weekâ€™s end and feel the difference! 
How parents talk to themselves teaches their kids how to talk to themselves. Girls, boys,  and teens learn from watching their parents.

message_guidance_5.eng: Briefly read the participantsâ€™ responses and make sure they are not insulting themselves and generally follow the example above. Any instances of intent of self-harm or harm to girls and boys should be reported appropriately.

ğŸ’¡ See how the positive self-talk is more supportive? ğŸ  Now, your turn! Share a time you talked negatively to yourself, and letâ€™s find and turn it into positive self-talk. Try doing this three times by the weekâ€™s end and feel the difference! 
How parents talk to themselves teaches their kids how to talk to themselves. Girls, boys,  and teens learn from watching their parents.
rows.message_guidance_5: Briefly read the participantsâ€™ responses and make sure they are not insulting themselves and generally follow the example above. Any instances of intent of self-harm or harm to girls and boys should be reported appropriately.

introduction.eng:
Ground rules make your WhatsApp Support Group a safe space for everyone. 

If someone forgets the ground rules, send the message below to remind them of their importance gently. 

If necessary, share a group reminder about the importance of maintaining a positive and respectful space. 

If, despite reminders, the parent continues not to follow the rules, notify your supervisor. 

You can remove the parent from the group as the last option, done only when you feel it is necessary. For example, if a member repeatedly (more than twice) shares unrelated content, uses inappropriate language, or disrespects another member. 

If you do remove someone from the group, it should be handled with sensitivity and respect. Make sure you talk privately with the parent, remind the group about ground rules, and notify your supervisor.

rows.title: Overview of the Crianza con Conciencia+ Programme

title.eng: Overview of the Crianza con Conciencia+ Programme

introduction.eng:
Welcome to the Crianza con Conciencia+ Positive Parenting Programme! 

Thank you for your commitment and dedication to supporting girls, boys, teens and families in your community. 
You are a shining star!

section_text_1.eng:
This guide is for YOU!! 
A comprehensive guide to help you deliver Crianza con Conciencia+ to families around you. 
Steps on how to introduce caregivers to the programme and support them
Specific information on the programmeâ€™s content.

section_text_2.eng:
It is important to follow this manual as closely as possible. However, manuals are only a guide to support you after what you have learned in the training workshop. 
What you deliver â€“ the content of the manual â€“ is only 20% of the programme. The rest 80%? Itâ€™s all about HOW you facilitate the programme and behave towards the parents.

section_text_3.eng: The core skills of a good facilitator are a mirror for parents to learn how to bring about the change we want to see in parents and the community. These include understanding stages of child development, praising and encouraging parents, using active listening skills, being consistent and compassionate, exploring problems, and finding solutions together.

section_text_4.eng:
Just as we say to the parents, â€œIt is what you do at home that makes the difference,â€ the same thing applies to you: â€œIt is how you interact with the parents in your group that makes the difference.â€ 

If you take the time to deliver a session before it begins, you will be more confident. If there is anything that you cannot remember or feel unsure of, contact another facilitator to practise with. 

Access the Facilitator Guide for your group by clicking on the icon above.

rows.section_text_3: The core skills of a good facilitator are a mirror for parents to learn how to bring about the change we want to see in parents and the community. These include understanding stages of child development, praising and encouraging parents, using active listening skills, being consistent and compassionate, exploring problems, and finding solutions together.
rows.section_text_4:
Just as we say to the parents, â€œIt is what you do at home that makes the difference,â€ the same thing applies to you: â€œIt is how you interact with the parents in your group that makes the difference.â€ 

If you take the time to deliver a session before it begins, you will be more confident. If there is anything that you cannot remember or feel unsure of, contact another facilitator to practise with. 

Access the Facilitator Guide for your group by clicking on the icon above.

rows.title: Guide for In-Person Onboarding

title.eng: Guide for In-Person Onboarding

introduction.eng: The Onboarding Session sets the tone for the entire Crianza con Conciencia+ programme. It is important to create a welcoming and safe space for the participants to feel at ease and familiarise themselves with the programme.

rows.introduction: The Onboarding Session sets the tone for the entire Crianza con Conciencia+ programme. It is important to create a welcoming and safe space for the participants to feel at ease and familiarise themselves with the programme.

rows.title: How to Conduct WhatsApp Group Chat Sessions

title.eng: How to Conduct WhatsApp Group Chat Sessions

introduction.eng:
The Crianza con Conciencia+ programme includes WhatsApp Groups with parents with pre-scripted messages that you share from Formando Conciencia+

The aim of this group is to provide parents with extra support during their Crianza con Conciencia+ journey.

section_text_1.eng:
**Make sure you have done the following before the onboarding session starts:** 

- Save the names and WhatsApp numbers of the parents assigned to you on your phone (if available), so you can easily confirm details during the onboarding session. 

- Create your WhatsApp group (with the temporary group name, icon, and description). The name of each WhatsApp group has the same structure:
â€œCrianza con Conciencia+â€
A name selected by the group 

When you create your temporary group name, you will use "Crianza con Conciencia+â€ 

You can keep your temporary group name or you can add a name to the temporary group name. For example, â€œCrianza con Conciencia+__HappyFamiliesâ€.

section_text_2.eng:
**Before conducting the chat sessions, make sure you:** 

Create a WhatsApp Group during the onboarding session. 
Identify the ground rules for the WhatsApp Group

**Structure for the chat sessions**: Day  1 (immediately after the onboarding session): Welcome, introductions, and reminder of home practice. 

Day 2: Send an encouraging message Day 3: Self-talk: WhatsApp Chat session on self-talk and stress

Day 4: Send an encouraging message Day 6: Checking in on parentsâ€™ experience and closing

**When to send the messages** 

You and your group will decide a time to chat during the onboarding session. Each chat session has a reminder message (Message 1) that you should send a few hours before the chat session. 

Send the remaining messages during the scheduled chat time.

section_title_3.eng: Share the messages in the chat session

section_text_3.eng:
Look for the "Chat Sessions" section on the Formando Conciencia+ homepage

Find the specific chat session you want to share and click on it.

Once you're on the content for that session, locate the "Share" icon. It should look like an arrow pointing upward or a box with an arrow, and it's used to share content. Click on the "Share" icon.

Select "WhatsApp" as your sharing option in the menu that appears.

Choose your Crianza con Conciencia+ Support Group from the list. 

Before you hit the "Send" button, make sure to add or change any necessary information like your name. 

Finally, click the "Send" button to share the content with your Crianza con Conciencia+ Support Group.

section_title_4.eng: Get Help with WhatsApp Support Group

section_text_4.eng:
If you require help while moderating your WhatsApp Support Group, the chat sessions provide a list of FAQs and potential solutions.

If you need support responding to a challenge shared by the parent during your chat session, see â€œCommon Challengesâ€ on the homepage. 

Follow the same instructions as Sharing Chat Messages to share the solutions to the challenges. 

If you encounter a challenge not covered in the chat session, kindly contact your supervisor for further guidance.

rows.title: How to Report on Programme Delivery

title.eng: How to Report on Programme Delivery

introduction.eng:
The Formando Conciencia+ also makes reporting on the delivery of Crianza con Conciencia+ much easier than paper forms.

After adding each parentâ€™s name to the App, you will be able to report on their participation during in-person and WhatsApp group sessions.

You will also report on your own experience, including the time spent conducting each session and whether you were able to do all the activities in the session.

section_text_1.eng:
Select the profile icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Choose â€œAbout youâ€ 

Type your name under â€œYour nameâ€ 

Select your state from the dropdown menu 
Tap Save

section_text_2.eng:
Select the profile icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Choose â€œAdd Parentâ€

Enter parent details in the form. To enter the parentâ€™s unique identifier (UID), ask them to text â€œIDâ€ on Crianza con Conciencia+. Copy the 6-digit number into the parent profile.

section_text_3.eng:
If two parents from the same family are participating in the programme, together, you must link their accounts. 

Once you have added the first parent profile, to add a second parent, select â€œAdd Parentâ€

Enter parent details in the form. To enter the parentâ€™s unique identifier (UID), ask them to text â€œIDâ€ on Crianza con Conciencia+. Copy the 6-digit number into the parent profile. 

Select â€œAdd Co-Parentâ€

Select the co-parent from available parent user profiles. 

Select â€œSaveâ€

*Both parent profiles will be updated to note the co-parent.*

section_text_4.eng:
Select the pencil icon from the bottom navigation bar. 

Select whether you are reporting on an in-person or WhatsApp session with your parents. 

Choose which session you are reporting on. 


Complete the report 

â°Specify the time spent on preparation, travel, and actual session delivery. 

âœ…Check the activities you completed (in-person) or the number of messages you sent (WhatsApp Group)

ğŸ”µSelecting the parents who participated in the session:

For in-person sessions, â€œparticipationâ€ is defined as parents who attended the session, in part or whole. 
For the WhatsApp group, â€œparticipationâ€ is defined as parents who have sent at least 1 message during the chat session. 

If you do not see a parentâ€™s name, then you need to add that parent to the App (see above).

section_text_5.eng:
Only edit an attendance report if you have made a mistake.

Select the pencil icon from the bottom of the navigation bar. 

Select whether you want to edit an in-person or WhatsApp session. 

Select the session that you want to edit.

Your previous selections will appear. You can now edit your selections and select â€œSaveâ€

rows.title: Parents began insulting themselves during the chat session

title.eng: Parents began insulting themselves during the chat session

introduction.eng: During our chat, parents might speak unkindly about themselves. If this happens, it's important to correct them gently. While it's okay to share examples of negative self-talk when asked, if it occurs in other parts of the conversation, the facilitator should step in to help guide the discussion positively.

section_text_1.eng:
If a parent is being unkind to themselves, they might already realize it. To help, gently suggest a kinder language. For example

Parent: "Iâ€™m an okay parent, even I often mess up."

Facilitator: "Thank you for sharing. Great job recognizing your strength. Let's re-word this unkind talk. How about:
ğŸ’š 'Iâ€™m an okay parent, even though Iâ€™m overwhelmed right now.'
ğŸ’› 'Even when I donâ€™t have all the answers.'
ğŸ’™ 'It's okay to make mistakes and learn from them.'

You can choose one of these or create a new one. Parents might not be used to positive self-talk so a little encouragement can go a long way!

section_text_2.eng: Remind parents that this space is a supportive community. Encourage parents to share words of encouragement and positive things they say to themselves. This helps create a supportive environment for everyone.

rows.title: Caregivers express intentions of self-harm or harm to their girls, boys, and teens during the session.

title.eng: Caregivers express intentions of self-harm or harm to their girls, boys, and teens during the session.

introduction.eng:
If a parent is showing intention to self-harm or harm to their girls and boys, remember, they may are experiencing an intense emotion. Remember, the best thing you can do is follow safeguarding protocols and refer them to services that can provide the help they need.

Report to your supervisor after sending the following message privately to the parent:

message_text_1.eng:
Dear [INSERT NAME], 

This space is here to support you. If you or someone else is in immediate danger, consider calling La LÃ­nea de la Vida at 800 911 2000 or SAPTEL at 55 5259 8121 for assistance.You can also type HELP in ParentText to find more resources for support. Your safety and well-being is important to us, and we are here to help.

message_guidance_1.eng: Write the name of the parent before sending the message.

rows.title: Parents could not turn negative self-talk into positive self-talk

title.eng: Parents could not turn negative self-talk into positive self-talk

introduction.eng:
At times, parents may find it challenging to transform negative self-talk into positive self-talk during the chat session. If this happens, remember that everyone moves at their own pace. Stay calm and offer support with a different perspective:

1ï¸âƒ£ Imagine someone you love is going through a similar situation.
2ï¸âƒ£ Consider what they might need to hear to feel better.
3ï¸âƒ£ Use the same words you identified and say them to yourself.

We're not aiming for perfection; you're doing your best with what you have. Keep practicing these steps, and gradually, the task will become easier.You can send the message below:

message_text_1.eng:
If you are struggling to say kind or caring words to yourselves, try this: 
1ï¸âƒ£ Imagine someone you love is going through a similar situation.
2ï¸âƒ£ Think about what they might need to hear to feel better.
3ï¸âƒ£ Use those same comforting words and say them to yourself.

Remember, you're not alone, and treating yourself with kindness matters.

rows.title: Spending one-on-one time

title.eng: Spending one-on-one time

introduction.eng:
Parenting can be challenging and many obstacles can get in the way.

Remember, your job isn't to solve their problems but to enable a conversation between parents to support one another. ğŸ”„

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for spending one-on-one time that we have encountered previously when delivering the programme. You can share the following messages as responses during your chat sessions when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I didnâ€™t have enough time to spend one-on-one time.

message_text_1.eng: Thank you for sharing. It can be hard to find time, especially when you have work, chores, and other responsibilities to do. ğŸ˜” You could try finding a chore to do together.

message_title_2.eng: My girl, boy or teen did not want to spend time with me.

message_text_2.eng: Thank you for sharing. It feels sad when your boy, girl, or teen doesn't want to spend time with you. ğŸ˜” Try suggesting a fun activity to do together.

message_title_3.eng: All my girl, boy or teen wanted to do was watch T.V. or play with a gadget.

message_text_3.eng:
It can be tough when your teen, girl, or boy seems focused on watching TV or playing with a gadget all the time. ğŸ˜Ÿ 

To connect with them and understand their interests, try asking them to show you something cool on the gadget. 

It's a simple way to engage with their world and spend time together. ğŸ“º

message_title_4.eng: My boy, girl, or teen did not want one-on-one time to end.

message_text_4.eng: I understand it can be tough when your girl, boy, or teen does not want one-on-one time to end. ğŸ˜£To make things smoother, try being clear about how much time you have together and give a gentle warning when the time is about to end. â°

message_title_5.eng: My boy, girl, or teen wanted to do activities that I could not do.

message_text_5.eng:
I can imagine it's challenging when your girl, boy, or teen wants to do activities that you find difficult. ğŸ˜”

A simple solution is to ask your boy, girl, or teen if you can join in by watching.  

This way, you're still involved and supportive, even if you can't participate directly. ğŸ¤

rows.title: Praising your girl, boy, or teen

title.eng: Praising your girl, boy, or teen

introduction.eng:
It is normal for caregivers to feel uncomfortable or have challenges when praising their boys, girls, and teens. They may at first think that praise will either inflate their girls, boys, or teens or is not part of their culture. 

It is important to remember that there are many different ways to praise boys, girls, and teens. Crianza con Conciencia+ focuses mainly on praise as a method to reinforce positive behaviour. We praise the behaviour more than just the girl, boy, or teen!

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for praising your girl, boy, or teen. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your weekly chat when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: I forgot to praise my boy, girl, or teen.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ’šIt can be difficult to juggle all the different things we need to do. 

ğŸŒ±Next time you spend one-on-one time, try and think of one thing you can praise them for. 

â˜€ï¸You can even say, â€œThank you for
spending time with me!â€

message_title_2.eng: I felt embarrassed or weird when praising my boy, girl, or teen.

message_text_2.eng:
â­Itâ€™s normal to feel uneasy about doing new things.

ğŸŒ·This is especially true of praise when we are not used to hearing it ourselves. 

ğŸ‘€But it will get easier with practice, I promise!

message_title_3.eng: I canâ€™t think of anything to praise my girl, boy, or teen.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸ””Start small! You donâ€™t have to select anything big to praise. 

ğŸ’¡Find a simple behaviour that your girl, boy, or teen does that you are happy about and tell them. Even something that they already do. 

â™¥ï¸ It will make a difference!

rows.title: Talking about feelings

title.eng: Talking about feelings

introduction.eng:
It is completely normal for parents to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings. Parents may be trying to recognise their emotions and communicate about them for the first time here.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for talking about feelings. 
You can share the following messages as responses during your chat session when parents share challenges with this topic.

message_title_1.eng: My girl, boy or teen did not want to share their emotions.

message_text_1.eng:
ğŸ’šI understand that sharing feelings is challenging when itâ€™s new. 

ğŸŒ±Be patient and keep providing them with the opportunity to start sharing. 

â˜€ï¸Be a model for your boys, girls, and teens by sharing your own feelings.

message_title_2.eng: I felt uncomfortable talking about my own feelings

message_text_2.eng:
â­It's okay to feel uncomfortable talking about your own feelings. 

ğŸ‘€A simple way to start is by using 'I feel...' 

ğŸŒ·For example, you could say, "I feel happy when we spend time together." Starting small like this can make it easier.

message_title_3.eng: Others in the household donâ€™t think itâ€™s a good idea to talk about emotions.

message_text_3.eng:
ğŸ””You can try talking to them about why it might be a good idea. 

ğŸ’¡Encourage them to try it first. Sometimes, just giving it a try can help everyone understand each other better.

message_title_4.eng: Others in the household donâ€™t think itâ€™s a good idea to talk about negative emotions.

message_text_4.eng:
ğŸ””Maybe you can have a chat with them about why it could be a good idea. 

ğŸ’¡Encourage them to give it a try! Talking openly about feelings can help everyone understand each other better.

message_title_5.eng: I donâ€™t know how to name some of the feelings I am experiencing.

message_text_5.eng:
âœ¨Naming feelings can be tough. 

ğŸ”„Try combining words you know, like happy or sad, and think about where you feel it in your body. 

ğŸ”´For example, if your chest feels tight, it might be stress. 

ğŸ”¶It's okay not to have all the words â€“ describe it the best you can.

ğŸŒ·For example, you could say, "I feel happy when we spend time together." Starting small like this can make it easier.
rows.message_title_3: Others in the household donâ€™t think itâ€™s a good idea to talk about emotions.
rows.message_text_3:
ğŸ””You can try talking to them about why it might be a good idea. 

ğŸ’¡Encourage them to try it first. Sometimes, just giving it a try can help everyone understand each other better.
rows.message_title_4: Others in the household donâ€™t think itâ€™s a good idea to talk about negative emotions.
rows.message_text_4:
ğŸ””Maybe you can have a chat with them about why it could be a good idea. 

ğŸ’¡Encourage them to give it a try! Talking openly about feelings can help everyone understand each other better.
rows.message_title_5: I donâ€™t know how to name some of the feelings I am experiencing.
rows.message_text_5:
âœ¨Naming feelings can be tough. 

ğŸ”„Try combining words you know, like happy or sad, and think about where you feel it in your body. 

ğŸ”´For example, if your chest feels tight, it might be stress. 

ğŸ”¶It's okay not to have all the words â€“ describe it the best you can.

rows.title: Setting routines

title.eng: Setting routines

introduction.eng:
Establishing routines can be difficult for parents at first. 

Parents may also not feel comfortable involving their girls, boys, or teens in establishing a routine. You can remind them that this will make it more likely that their boy, girl, or teen will follow the rule and will also help their girl, boy, or teen learn responsibilities.

Here are some common challenges and possible solutions for setting routines for one-on-one time and other activities: 
You can share the following messages as responses to the challenges:

message_title_1.eng: Parent should be the one setting the rule, not the girl, boy, or teen.

message_text_1.eng:
When we establish rules together with our
children, that helps the family to understand each other better.

 The rules will be more realistic and children will be more willing and able to follow the rules.

message_title_2.eng: We made the routine, but my boy, girl, or teen does not follow it.

message_text_2.eng:
I get that it's challenging when your girl, boy, or teen isn't following the routine you set. ğŸ˜”

Think about your routine â€“ is it fair and realistic? What can your girl, boy, or teen actually do? Adjust the routine if necessary. 

Praise your boy, girl, or teen when they do follow the routine.

message_title_3.eng: When we tried to set a routine, we got into an argument

message_text_3.eng: When did you set the routine? Was the girl, boy or teen calm? How did you approach it? If you or your girls, boys, or teens are hungry or tired, it is better to talk about the routines at a later point.

message_title_4.eng: We were not able to stick to the routine

message_text_4.eng: Make sure you have a routine that can be kept easily. For example, try having one meal together every week instead of every night.

rows.title: No one volunteered to be group admin

title.eng: No one volunteered to be group admin

introduction.eng:
It may be difficult to find volunteers to become group admin. If no one volunteers to lead the group, you can send the message below to close the group. 

Wait a couple days before closing because someone might still volunteer!

message_text_1.eng:
Thank you for sharing your thoughts ğŸ’™

Since we donâ€™t have any volunteers for group admin, I will be closing this WhatsApp Support Group at the end of the Programme. 

Remember, you can still continue your Crianza con Conciencia+ journey with your family!

rows.title: How to hand over to Group Admin

title.eng: How to hand over to Group Admin

introduction.eng:
Once 2 volunteers to be group admin are selected, schedule a WhatsApp call with them.

When youâ€™re done with the call, you can send the guidelines as messages to remind them what you discussed.

section_title_1.eng: What to cover in the WhatsApp Call?

section_text_1.eng:
Thank the parent for volunteering to lead the WhatsApp group.  

While engaging with other parents in the group, keep the following in mind:
ğŸ”µGreet parents when engaging with them.
ğŸ”µRespect what participants share and be aware of different ages, genders, values and circumstances.
ğŸ”µEncourage parents to share and respond to each other - and praise them for it.
ğŸ”µRemind parents of ground rules when needed.
ğŸ”µModel the behaviour you want to see among the parents.

If the parent needs any prompts for discussion, share the following: 

Let us celebrate our successes! What was something positive you experienced when you tried one of the Crianza con Conciencia+ skills with your boy, girl, or teen?

Trying out new skills can be hard at first. What was something difficult that you experienced when you tried a Crianza con Conciencia+ skill with your girl, boy, or teen at home?
Remind the parent that they are not obligated to respond to messages all times. Participants may send messages at any time during the week. To keep your workload manageable, you can respond to messages once or twice a day, depending on your schedule. 

Ask them if they have any questions. 

Remind the parent that unfortunately, you will no longer be able to participate in the WhatsApp group.

message_title_1.eng: Send this message after your WhatsApp Call

message_text_1.eng:
Hi! Thank you for volunteering to lead the group discussions.

ğŸ‘‹Greet parents when engaging with them.

ğŸ’›Respect what participants share and be aware of different ages, genders, values and circumstances. 

ğŸ…Encourage parents to share and respond to each other - and praise them for it.

ğŸ””Remind parents of ground rules when needed.

ğŸ”‘Model the behaviour you want to see among the parents.

message_title_2.eng: When should the group admin respond to messages?

message_text_2.eng:
*When should you respond to messages?*

â°Participants may send messages at any time during the week. To keep your workload manageable, you can respond to messages once or twice a day, depending on your schedule. 

ğŸ‘You can also respond to messages with a relevant emoji or short response when you can.
